loans.use: buy a CNG kit for her son's rickshaw

loans.name: Orozkul

texts.ru: Орозкул 49 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывает 3 детей. У Орозкул - среднее образование, работает помощником воспитателя в местном детском саду, в качестве дополнительного дохода для своей семьи Орозкул занимается животноводством, стартовав 19 лет назад, с покупки скота на 1,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Орозкул, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 4 дойные коровы, 10 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет 5,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Орозкул обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 20,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Орозкул планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на проведение свадебного торжества для сына.
texts.en: Orozkul is 49, married, and raising 3 children together with her husband.  She has the equivalent of a high school education, and works as an assistant at a local preschool; she also raises livestock on the side, having started 19 years ago with 1,000 somoni worth of animals.  Thanks to her persistent efforts, her farm currently has 4 dairy cows and 10 sheep, while her monthly income is nearly 5,000 somoni.  To further develop her farm, Orozkul is seeking a loan from Bai Tushum and Partners; she hopes to borrow 20,000 somoni to buy more sheep for her farm, and plans to use her increased income due to the loan to buy even more livestock, as well as to save money for her son's wedding reception.

loans.use: to buy sheep

loans.name: Fabian Alexis

texts.es: Fabian joven de 25 años de edad reside en Tegucigalpa estudia actualmente Arquitectura en la Universidad José Cecilio del Valle en Tegucigalpa, a pesar de haber postergado sus estudios 2 años por problemas económicos se considera un joven perseverante y decidido, recibe el apoyo de su madre y su padre quien se dedica a la venta de libros educativos para el sostén de su familia. Solicita el apoyo financiero a CREHO para cancelar sus 5 últimas clases y su proyecto de graduación que le falta para concluir sus estudios y de esa forma poder superarse profesionalmente y ser un apoyo para sus padres. Mis aspiraciones son graduarme en el mes de Agosto del 2014 y continuar profesionalizándome, sé que tengo un gran potencial en mi área y he decidido aprovechas las oportunidad que mi país me da y contribuir a su desarrollo.
texts.en:
Fabian, 25, lives in Tegucigalpa, where he's currently studying architecture at the Universidad José Cecilio del Valle.  He considers himself to be a persevering and determined young man, despite having postponed his studies for two years because of financial problems.  He has the support of his mother and his father, who earns a living and supports the family selling educational books.

Fabian's requesting the financial support of CREHO to pay for his last five courses and the graduation project he has to do.

This way he can finish his program and be able to improve himself professionally and be a help to his parents.  "My goals are to graduate in August 2014 and keep on becoming a professional.  I know I have great potential in my field, and I've decided to make the most of the opportunity my country gives me and to contribute to its development."

loans.use: to pay his monthly expenses

loans.name: Firdos

texts.en:
Firdos is a 45-year-old married woman living in the Lahore region of Pakistan. She has three daughters and two sons. One daughter and the two sons are married. Her other two daughters remain with her.

Firdos’ husband owns a fabric business, buying cloth from wholesalers then selling it to retailers. Her husband is an old man, but he continues to work for the sake of his family. The problem is that in order for their daughters to marry, they need dowries but the family’s monthly income is too low to save for this purpose.

Therefore, Firdos is applying for a 25,000 PKR loan through BRAC Pakistan to be put toward additional fabric for her husband to sell and so increase his profits. She hopes that their savings will allow them to build up money for dowries for their daughters.

Firdos dreams of bright futures for her daughters, a steady business and a peaceful life. She is very thankful for Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy fabric for resale.

loans.name: Moeng's Group

texts.en:
Moeng is in her late 20s and a mother of three children. She grows rice in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. Farming rice is a common occupation in her region and is the primary source of her family’s income. The farm earns them on average 27,000 KHR a day.

Moeng is the leader of this two-member group. She and her co-borrower are applying for a 1,500,000 KHR loan through VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. She will use her 1,000,000 KHR loan portion to buy fertilizer and insecticides for her farmland. She hopes that she can gain a better yield than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide for her farmland

loans.name: Ader

texts.en:
Ader is 45 years old.  He lives with his wife and six children. 

He has worked in the transportation business for more than six years.  This has helped him create a modest improvement in his family's living conditions because he’s able to provide for their needs.  He is a responsible and hard-working man who is aiming for a bright future. 

Ader knows that he could achieve it with strong determination and good condition of his motorcycle.  He is requesting a PHP 7,000 loan to buy some spare parts and maintain his business.  If his requested loan is permitted, he will obtain higher income and provide his family with a better way of living.

loans.use: to buy some spare parts and maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Chreb's Group

texts.en:
Chreb is 33 years old and the mother of four children. Nowadays, two of her children are in school. She is a local villager from Battambang province.

To strive for a living, she does rice farming on one and a half hectares of land with the support of her husband. She has been involved in her current business for 10 years, earning about KHR 13,300 per day. Including this loan, she is a fourth-time borrower, whereas her joint member is a second-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). 

Chreb's past three loans have enabled her to upgrade her lifestyle better than before. Now, she is leading a group of two to get a new loan. 

As the leader, Chreb will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her crop. She hopes that she can gain a good yield from her crop and make more income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide for her crop

loans.name: Chhouy's Group

texts.en:
Chhouy, 57, lives in a rural village of Banteay Meanchey province’s Mongkul Borey district, Cambodia. She is married and has seven children. For the last 37 years, Chhouy has been farming rice and catching fish. To supplement the income, her husband also works for others for a fee. The current business earns her about 40,000 KHR per day.

Chhouy has been a member of Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for four cycles already, and she completely repaid the loans. She has used the past loan wisely and successfully to improve her family’s livelihood. 

Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy materials for renovating her old house. She hopes this loan will enable her to have a decent house for living in.

loans.use: to buy materials for renovating her old house.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkol Borey District

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en:
Mom is aged 59 years and married with one child. She and her husband have worked very hard for years to support their family by farming rice. The current business earns them about KHR 36,000 per day and they manage to save about KHR 12,000 each day after expenses. 

This is the first loan for Mom with VisionFund. She is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to better support her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Chheang's Group

texts.en:
Chheang, 55, is a father of five children. He is a citizen from Kampong Cham province, where he does his rice-cropping on a one-hectare area with the support of his wife. This business has returned him almost 27,000 KHR per day. 

Never having been with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner), Chheang teamed up with a group of three to get the first loan. He and his joint borrowers are seeking 1,000,000 KHR each.  As the leader, he will spend his loan portion to buy rice seed and fertilizer for his crop. He hopes that he will boost his crop on time and make a good income.

loans.use: to buy rice seed and fertilizer for his crop.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Sophat's Group

texts.en:
Sophat is the young mother of three kids residing in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, 

Sophat is a rice grower on two hectares of farmland. This core business has returned her about KHR 18,000 per day. This is the first microloan for Sophat with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner).

Now, she is in a group of two to get the new loan. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her crop. 

She hopes that she can gain a good crop output and get a good selling price to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her crop

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana is taking a loan of $1000 to improve her business. She is running a second hand clothing business that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store such as trousers, shorts, and shirts. She opened her kiosk a year ago with her own working capital of $200. Susana is a hard-working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy trousers, shorts, shirts, etc.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 41 years old and married to Ndungu.  They have four children who are in school.

She is in the business of hawking clothes in Naivasha which she has practiced for four years. She has applied for her first loan from Kadet to enable her to purchase stock of clothing to sell. With the anticipated profits, she plans to pay school fees and buy more stock for her business.  She also hopes to own her own house in Naivasha in the near future.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a married mother of three children, two of whom attend school and one is still young. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a business selling clothes, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge with the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 50,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothing for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothing for resale.

loans.name: Cleementina

texts.en:
Cleementina is the married mother of six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.
 
Cleementina has operated a posho mill (grinding machine) business for the past three years, grinding cereals such as maize, ground nuts, etc.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, green grams, ground nuts, and spare parts for her business. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, green grams, ground nuts, and spare parts for her business

loans.name: Sokhon

texts.en:
Sokhon is a young mother with one small child. She lives in the Bovel district of the Battambang province. To support her living, she does rice farming as the main source of income. She has been involved in this business for four years.  

This is a first-time loan for Sokhon with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). Sokhon is seeking 3,000,000 KHR in order to buy insecticide and fertilizer and to pay a plowing fee. She hopes that this loan will help her to support her agribusiness promptly so she can earn a decent income to provide decent food for her family every day.

loans.use: to buy insecticide and fertilizer and to pay a  plowing fee.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 55 years old and married to Peter.  They have two children who are in school.

She has an electronic business in Naivasha which she has been running for three years, and she has applied for her first loan from KADET to enable her to purchase stock of DVDs, among other electronics.  

With the anticipated profits, she plans to pay school fees.  In the near future, she hopes to own the biggest electronic shop in Naivasha.

loans.use: To purchase stock of DVDs, among other electronics

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is 40 years old and married and blessed with two children, who are in school.

She has a boutique business in Naivasha that she has operated for three years.  She has applied for a first loan from Kadet Ltd to enable her to purchase stocks of clothes for sale. With the anticipated profit, she plans to pay school fees and buy more stock for her business.

In the near future, she hopes to open another boutique in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy stocks of clothes to sell

loans.name: Rahab

texts.en:
Rahab is 48 years old, married to Joseph, and they are supporting ten children aged between twenty and five years old.

She has been in the farming business in Ndunyu Njeru for nine years and has applied for her fifth loan from KADET Ltd., to enable her to buy fertilizer and seeds. With the anticipated profits, she plans to pay school fees and expand her farming business.

In the near future, she hopes to apply for a bigger loan from KADET Ltd. to enable her to expand her farming business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman, with four children, one who attends school and three of whom are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past one year, she has operated a business of selling leso clothes ( women's wrap). She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase 40 pieces of lesos for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 40 pieces of lesos (women's wrap) for resale.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos, a 30-year-old man, lives with his wife, Helny, 34 years old, and his two children, Revo, 10, and in the fifth grade of elementary school, and Keigel, 2. Amos has been running a kiosk business for three years. The earned income from this business enables him to cover their living expenses. 

Currently, Amos wants to improve his business by completing the stock at his kiosk. By selling more items at his kiosk, he can generate more income. Therefore, Amos would like to request a loan of IDR 4,000,000 from TLM. He will spend the loan on sugar, coffee, shampoo, bath soap, detergent, instant noodles, etc.

loans.use: to buy sugar, coffee, shampoo, bath soap, detergent, instant noodles, etc.

loans.name: Mince

texts.en:
Mince is a 36-year-old woman who is married to Samuel, 43 years old. They have three children from their marriage: Baby, 7, and Glen, 6, both  elementary school students; the third is Grace, 4,  who has just attended early childhood education. 

Mince’s husband is a disabled parking man, but a month ago he was entrusted as a security guard at a newly opened hotel downtown. 

In order to support  her husband in fulfilling the family needs, she established a kiosk business three years ago, using her own capital in the amount of IDR 150,000. The kiosk is located in their living room, selling snacks and soft drinks.  Sometimes she also works as a washerwoman from home to home, as well as a scavenger who collects plastic items that can be recycled for sale at the collecting agent of used goods. 

The dream of a brand-new kiosk separated from her living room has led her to apply for an individual loan of IDR 4,500,000. The loan will be spent to purchase a small new kiosk next to her house and to purchase more stocks, such as detergents, soaps, cooking oil, etc.

loans.use: to purchase a small new kiosk next to her house and to purchase more stocks, such as detergents, soaps, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 50-year-old mother from Gem West location in Homabay, which is located within the western part of Kenya. She supports 10 people in her family.

Jane sells cereals, and she has been doing this for the past 35 years.  She gets a monthly income of KES 7,000.

She is requesting her first loan with KADET LTD, which she will use to improve her business. She will use the anticipated profit to buy a cow.

Her dream is to employ other workers and have a bright future.

loans.use: to improve her business selling cereals.

loans.name: Jose Oscar

texts.es: José Oscar de veintiocho años de edad vive junto a su compañera de vida y su hija de tres meses. El es auxiliar de albañil y trabaja duro todos los días para lograr salir adelante con los gastos del hogar; José Oscar es un hombre emprendedor y responsable, le gusta luchar por su familia pero debido a su situación económica no ha contado con los recursos suficientes para una casa, por eso desea construir una pequeña champa de lamina con polines de madera resistentes, en el terreno que le dejo su madre, espera realizar el trabajo lo más pronto posible pero necesita capital para la compra de materiales, por eso solicita a FUSAI un crédito que le permita comprar lamina galvanizada, madera y clavos, se ahorrara la mano de obra. José Oscar está muy contento con la ayuda y se compromete a cancelar en el periodo establecido.
texts.en:
José Oscar is 28 and lives with his partner and their 3 months old daughter.

He is a builder's assitant and works hard every day to make due on their household expenses.

José Oscar is an enterprising and responsible man.  He enjoys fighting for his family, but because of the economic situation, he hasn't had sufficient means for a house.  Therefore, he wants to build a small rustic cabin of rolled metal and durable wooden poles in the land his mother left him.

He hopes to achieve this job as soon as possible, but needs capital to buy the materials.  That's why he's asking FUSAI for a loan that will enable him to buy the rolls laminated metal, wood and nails.  It will allow him to save on labor costs.

José Oscar is very pleased with the help and is committed to paying the debt within the established time-frame.

loans.use: to buy rolled galvanized metal, wood and nails

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
Srey is 40 years old and married. Her household consists of six children.

She and her husband strive for a living via rice farming, which has returned them about KHR 32,000 per day. 

Though she has never been with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) before, she has formed a group of three to get a new loan. 

As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her crop. She hopes that she can gain a good yield from her agribusiness, better than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her crop

loans.name: Robby

texts.en:
Robby is a 46-year-old man and is married to Agustina, 40.  They’re blessed with four children: Rafli, 15, in 3rd grade of Junior High School; Riani, 10, in 5th grade of Elementary School; and Yosua and Kaleb, twins, 7, in 2nd grade of Elementary School. Robby has been running a travel agent business for the past 3 months. Before running this business, Robby worked as building contractor. With his own capital, he started this travel agent business. The earned income from this business enables him to cover his living expenses. 

Currently Robby wants to improve his business capacity by selling tickets for international flights. Therefore, he requests a loan in the amount of IDR 10,000,000 from TLM.

loans.use: to purchase tickets for international flights

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a married woman, with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past six years, she has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major business  challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase soap, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase soap, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Kean's Group

texts.en:
Kean is 52 years old, an inhabitant from Battambang province, and a breadwinner in her family consisting of two little kids.
 
For the sake of her family, she grows pineapples, which has returned her about KHR 19,500 per day to cover daily expenses. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. 

Kean and her co-borrower are new to VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). Kean is seeking KHR 700,000, and her co-borrower is applying for KHR 1,000,000. 

As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her pineapple trees. She hopes to triple her yield and get a good selling price.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her pineapple trees

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is 27 years old from Gem East loaction in Homabay County which is located in the Western part of Kenya.  She supports 5 people in her family and is married to Paul, who is also a business man and supports the family. Together they have 5 children who are 15, 12, 9, 6 and 3 years old respectively.

Pamela sells cereals, and she has been doing this business for the last 15 years.  She generates a monthly income of KES 5,000. She has requested her first loan with KADET LTD, which she will use to increase her working capital.  She will use the anticipated profits to expand her business.

Her dreams and hopes are to have better living standards and to educate all her children.

loans.use: to purchase cereals.

loans.name: Meresa

texts.en:
Meresa is 39 year old lady hailing from Migori county. She is a widow and has 2 children who are 19 and 2 years old respectively.

She has a tailoring center she has operated for 5 years and she earns a monthly income of Kes 4000. She is requesting her first loan with KADET LTD, which she will use to add more stock of cloth material. She will use the anticipated profit to better her future.

Her dream is to have a stable future and a good business.

loans.use: To improve her tailoring business.

loans.name: Magret

texts.en: Magret, a widow with four children, wants to thank Ugafode for how far it has brought her. She managed to complete her residential house that had stalled for a long time through the use of the Ugafode Micro mortgage loan. She now wants this loan to finish her house with plaster and cement. She thanks Ugafode for the help because she has also been able to educate her children with access to a school fees loan. In the photo you see Magret with Ugafode staff. She will use income from selling cattle to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy building materials for her house.

loans.name: Nget's Group

texts.en: Nget is 38 years old and married. He has two children to cater for. He covers the daily cost of living for his entire household via pineapple farming which he has been involved with for 10 years. Now, Nget is a leader of a borrowers group of two. He and his colleague are first-time borrowers with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and they are seeking a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, he will spend his loan portion to buy fertilizer to boost the  output of his  cash-crop. He hopes that he can make more income from his business to improve his living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to boost his crop yield.

loans.name: Maqsoodan

texts.en:
Maqsoodan, aged, 40, is a responsible mother and is living happily in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. This is her 1st loan with BRAC; she is a new member. She is taking this loan according to needs of her family.

She belongs to a poor family and it is very difficult for her to fulfill all the household expenses with her poor earnings.  In fact, her husband is a hawker by profession and sells types of hair oil by bicycle.  He sells avocado oil, castor oil, coconut oil, olive oil, rosemary oil, safflower oil etc. He calls loudly to the consumers to offer all these hair oils and he is very famous for hair protecting oils.  He wants to buy a large quantity of hair oil to sell for the growth of his business and to overcome the poverty. Therefore, Maqsoodan requested a loan for her husband, so that he could buy more quantity of hair oil. 

Maqsoodan is very impressed with this honorable support. She says thanks to Kiva and to its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy avocado oil, castor oil, coconut oil, olive oil, rosemary oil, and safflower oil to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay graduation fees for her degree in tourism management

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is 27 years old. He lives in Gaza with his wife; he was recently married.

For the past two years, he has been running his own grocery store, which helped him in gathering money and fund his marriage. He sells different kinds of food stuff, such as soft drinks and kids stuff. He hopes that this youth loan will allow him to buy a refrigerator and shelves. He plans to open a supermarket in the future. 

Khaled is very grateful to everyone who helps him achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator and shelves for his grocery store.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 33 years old and is in the transport industry. He is married to Tuta, a shopkeeper, and together they are blessed with four children. Daniel has been in the transport industry for the past three years with a monthly income of ksh 9000 which he uses to support his family. 

Daniel is applying for his second loan term with KADET after repaying the previous loans successfully. He will use the loan to add stock to his wife’s retail shop such as sugar, stationery, cosmetics, etc. 

With the expected profit from the business he will buy a piece of land to start farming. 

His hopes and dreams are to educate his children and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to add stock to his wife’s retail shop such as sugar, stationery, cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Mupa

texts.en:
Mupa is asking for a loan because she believes that through it she will improve her business.  The previous loan enabled her to to save money for her goat meat selling business. 
She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses. The loan of KES 40,000 she is requesting will help her purchase five goats for her business.

loans.use: to purchase five goats for her business

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is a primary milk producing area. He has 1 child and has been doing this work for 5 years. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Adding value to agricultural products to fetch more income through operating a food kiosk." His biggest challenge is "High costs of transport reduces the margin earned."  Animals on the farm have been given no names.

Kenneth was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Was first introduced to Juhudi Lilimo through a group member in Juhudi Kilimo."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session and replied: "How to work in a group to gain financial freedom and minimise default."

His highest monthly expense is transportation costs. When asked "How will this loan benefit his family?", Kenneth replied "Will put up a dairy unit as a start for dairy keeping."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated.  Kenneth owns "cow, poultry ,pump, but does not own pig, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile."  Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household "mosquito net" but does not have "electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD."

loans.use: To put up a dairy unit.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 32-year-old man from Migori, which is found in Kenya. He supports 3 people in his family and is a married man. He has four children who are 3, 5, 7 and 8 years old respectively.

He sells secondhand shoes, a business he has been doing for the last 12 years. He gets a monthly income of KES 90,000. He has requested a third loan from KADET Ltd., which he will use to increase his stock. He will use the anticipated profit to grow his business.

His dream is to have a better life.

loans.use: to increase his stock.

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan is 39 years old and the father of 3 children, all of whom are currently studying in school. For the last five years, he has earned a living by selling cereals in Malindi, where he earns a monthly profit of 5,000 KES. 

Nathan was introduced to Kenya Agency for Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) by a credit officer, and he is applying for his first loan of KES 20,000 to purchase additional stocks of cereals needed for his business.

He will use the profit from the business to pay for school fees for his children, purchase food for his family, and expand his current business. Nathan hopes to open his own cereal depot in future to improve his family's financial stability.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of cereals for his business.

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en: Samnang is 43 years old and blessed with three children. She is a villager from Battambang province. To deal with the daily cost of living, she tailors clothes. She has been involved in this business since she was 23 years old. This is not a first loan for Samnang with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner).  The past loans, which she has repaid with success, have enabled her to improve her living conditions. For this cycle, she is seeking an education loan to pay for the tuition fee and school materials for her son who is willing to pursue a bachelor's degree majoring in management. She hopes that her son can get a good academic background and get a good job after graduation.

loans.use: To pay for her son's tuition fee and school materials

loans.name: Kira Tangni Group

texts.es:
Maricela es una señora emprendedora y amistosa, líder del Banco Comunal; está casada, tiene 5 hijos, dos son mayores de edad y tres son adolescentes que se encuentran estudiando. A sus 46 años de edad, ha organizado a nueve mujeres del municipio de Waspam alrededor de una panadería, con el propósito de contribuir a mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus familias, generando ingresos que les permita cubrir necesidades básicas de alimentación, educación y vestido.

Hace dos años comenzaron horneando pan con un horno artesanal en casa de doña Maricela. Recientemente, con apoyo de una ONG Internacional lograron construir el local equipado con Horno de leña, en el cual alcanzan cinco sartenes, molino para amasar el pan y mesa de trabajo.

Gracias a la iniciativa de doña Maricela y las capacitaciones que reciben sobre reposterías, han podido diversificar sus productos. Solicitan financiamiento a Pana Pana, para comprar y aumentar la cantidad de insumos para producir más pan. Con las ganancias que perciban, lo ahorraran, para comprar vitrinas donde ofertarán al público sus productos.

El sueño de Maricela  es lograr mejorar su vivienda y establecer un negocio de refresquería y venta de nacatamales.

Edelmira, es integrante del Banco comunal, tiene 36 años, se dedica a las actividades de la agricultura y también atiende su pequeña pulpería. Solicita préstamo para comprar más mercadería para su negocio. Su sueño es apoyar a sus 7 hijos para que salgan adelante. 

Olencia, es otra integrante que tiene 20 años de edad, está casada, tiene 4 hijos; el préstamo que solicita es para comprar mercancía para su pulpería, tales como: arroz, harina y azúcar. Su sueño es ampliar su pequeño negocio y construir su vivienda de concreto (cemento).

Aida, es una mujer emprendedora de 34 años y solicita financiamiento para comprar mercadería para ampliar su pulpería y elaborar pan. Su sueño es tener su propio local para su negocio, establecer una refresquería y repostería, y que sus hijos se conviertan en profesionales.

Valeria, solicita financiamiento para mejorar su vivienda, especialmente el techo que está en malas condiciones. Su sueño es construir su casa de concreto y apoyar a sus tres hijos menores de edad para que estudien y lleguen a ser futuros profesionales.

Breonet, tiene 38 años de edad, es madre soltera y solicita financiamiento para formar parte de la panadería y comprar los insumos necesarios. Su sueño es sacar adelante a sus tres hijos.

Ana, tiene 40 años de edad, está casada y tiene 4 hijos. Desde hace 2 años tiene una pequeña pulpería en su vivienda, por lo que requiere de un préstamo para comprar más mercadería, particularmente granos básicos. 

Selda, es madre soltera con 3 hijos y se dedica a labores de enfermería. Actualmente solicita financiamiento para reparación del techo de su vivienda. Su sueño es que su hijo mayor, que está enfermo, recupere su salud y continúe sus estudios.

Anidia, tiene 34 años, tiene 4 hijos y cuenta con una pequeña pulpería que logró establecer con apoyo económico de su esposo y un primer crédito recibido de Pana Pana. Actualmente, solicita financiamiento para comprar más mercadería para su pequeño negocio.
texts.en:
Maricela is an enterprising and friendly woman who is leader of the communal bank. She is married and has five children; two are adults and three are teenagers who are going to school. At 46, she has organized nine women from the municipality of Waspam around a bakery, with the aim of helping  improve the living conditions of their families and generating income that will allow them to cover basic necessities such as food, education and clothing.

Two years ago they began baking bread with an artisanal oven located in Maricela's home. Recently, with the support of an international NGO they managed to build a shop, equipped with a wood-fired oven that will take up to five pans, a mill for kneading dough and a work table.

Thanks to Maricela's initiative and the training they receive on making pastries, they been able to diversify their products. They are requesting financing from Pana Pana to buy more ingredients in order to produce more bread. From the profits they earn, they will save money to buy display cases where they will offer their products to the public. Maricela's dream is to succeed in improving her house and setting up her business selling refreshments and nacatamales (Nicaraguan stuffed tamales). 

Edelmira is a member of the communal bank. She is 36 years old and works in agriculture; she also runs her small general store. She is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise for her business. Her dream is to help her seven children get ahead in life. 

Olencia is another member. She is 20 years old, married, and has four children. The loan she is requesting is to buy merchandise for her general store, such as rice, flour and sugar. Her dream is to expand her small business and finish building her cement-block house. 

Aida is an enterprising woman of 34, and she is requesting financing to buy merchandise for expanding her general store and making bread. Her dream is to have her own shop for her business, to set up a pastry and refreshments stand, and to see her children to become professionals. 

Valeria is requesting financing to improve her home, especially the roof, which is in poor repair. Her dream is to finish building her cement-block house and help her three minor children to go to school and succeed in becoming professionals someday.

Breonet is 38 years old, a single mother, and is requesting financing to become part of the bakery and to buy the necessary ingredients. Her dream is to help her three children get ahead in life. 

Ana is 40 years old, married, and has four children. She has had a small general store in her home for two years and needs a loan to buy merchandise, particularly basic staples. 

Selda is a single mother with three children, and works as a nurse. Currently she is requesting a loan to repair the roof of her home. Her dream is for her eldest son, who is sick, to recover his health and continue his education. 

Anidia is 34 years old and has four children. She has a small general store which she managed to set up with her husband's financial support and the first loan received from Pana Pana. Currently she is requesting financing to buy more merchandise for her small business.

loans.use: To buy more supplies in order to produce more bread: flour, sugar, yeast, lard, butter.

loans.name: Kilombero Group

texts.en:
Kwirabi, who is in her late thirties, is married, with two children, a boy and a girl, both in school. 

For three years now, Kwirabi has been running a business selling freshwater fish, which she buys from lake zones. She starts working from 4:00 a.m. and works to 7:00 p.m. per working day and is able to make an excellent profit. 

This will be her fifth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. Kwirabi used her previous loans to buy more freshwater fish and bought a business freezer for her fish. She managed to pay back all her previous loans successfully. 

With the business profit she received, she paid school fees for her children, paid household expenses, reinvested back in her business, and saved the remaining to her bank account. 

Kwirabi will use this loan to buy more freshwater fish to resell. She dreams that one day she will be able to build a house and became a known business person. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Kilombero," which totals two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more freshwater fish to resell.

loans.name: Tia Maria Group

texts.en:
Caroline is the featured borrower of Tia Maria’s group. She got along with her group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, because they have always been neighbors and friends.
 
Caroline is a 36-year-old married mother of 4 children. She has been selling clothes and sunglasses at her house since four years ago. Her husband’s low salary and their family’s increasing needs encourages her more to work hard at expanding her business. That's why she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, to buy newly released clothes and underwear for the coming autumn/winter seasons.

Caroline is at the center of the picture, sitting. As for the other group members: Sahar is the first one from the right with a purple top and Daed is the first one from the left, standing behind Caroline.

loans.use: to buy newly released clothes and underwear for the coming autumn/winter seasons.

loans.name: Hon

texts.en:
Hon is a 43-year-old married woman, the mother of five grown-up children. She lives in a thatched house with her family in Prey Veng province. 

Hon has been engaged in the farming business for years, and she has also run a small grocery store from her home for additional income. This is the source of her income. 

As shown in the photo, she is standing in front of a latrine that had just been built in the past few weeks with the loan she has had from the HKL branch office in the province. She is happy to have a latrine for use by her household.  This will improve their health and protect them from spreading diseases caused by waste. 

In the future, Hon hopes to build a strong business and save money to make home improvements.

loans.use: to build a latrine for use by her household.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 40 years old, is from Olkalou. .He is married to Tabitha who is a farmer and they have three children who are 13, 11 and 2 years old.

He is a farmer practicing mixed farming and he has been in this occupation for the last 10 years. To diversify his sources of income, John has applied for his seventh loan of KSHS 100,000 from Kadet Ltd, which will be used to buy planting seeds, a heifer and tree seedlings.

His current monthly income is KSHS 20,000 and his plan is to use the anticipated profits from his expanded business to pay school fees for his children and to pay back his loan to Kadet Ltd.

He hopes that in the future, he will become an established dairy farmer

loans.use: To buy a heifer, planting seeds and tree seedlings

loans.name: Bunna

texts.en: Bunna, 31, is married and blessed with four children who are still in school. She strives to make a living from rice and cassava farming. To supplement the family’s income, her husband runs a small motorbike repair store in the area. Bunna has been involved in her current business for 11 years.  This is the third loan for Bunna with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has succeeded in repaying her past loans and they have enabled her to support her business better than before. For this loan cycle, she is seeking 1,500,000 KHR in order to pay for weeding fees and to buy necessary materials to support her husband’s business. She hopes that she can gain a good income from her crop so she can keep her kids in school until tertiary level.

loans.use: To pay someone to weed her farm

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos, está acompañado vive con su compañera de vida y sus hijos, su negocio consiste en venta de pan en bicicleta, su recorrido inicia 7:00 a. m. y finaliza 2:00 p.m., no tiene inconveniente que le evite ejercer su actividad más sin embargo tiene la necesidad de aumentar sus ingresos, por lo que está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar una plancha para hacer pupusas, maíz, aceite y otros.
Su sueño es establecer otra actividad económica que le dé más ingresos, mejorar la infraestructura de su casa para ampliar su negocio, tener más clientes y darle a su familia mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Carlos lives with his life partner and their children. His business consists of selling bread from a bicycle. He begins his rounds at 7 a.m. and finishes at 2 p.m. He has no difficulties that prevent him from carrying on his business, however he needs to increase his income, so he is requesting a loan so that he can buy a griddle for making pupusas, as well as corn, cooking oil and other supplies. 

His dream is to establish another business that will give him more income; to improve the infrastructure of his house in order to expand his business, have more customers and provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a griddle for making pupusas, as well as corn, cooking oil, and other supplies.

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en:
Fridah is 25 years old and married to David.  They are blessed with two children, aged 4 and 2 years.  

Fridah runs a retail shop in Kipkata and has been in this business for a period of 5 years, earning an income of KES 10,000.

Fridah is now servicing her 3rd loan of KES 70,000 from KADET LTD and wishes to purchase stocks of sugar, tea leaves and washing detergents among other business items for resale.  The profits she earns will be used to repay the loan and add more stock.  Her dream is to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: buy sugar, tea, washing detergents, etc. to sell

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en:
Jemima lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is extremely fertile for agriculture. She has 3 children.   Her primary income sources are from eggs, crops, and personal business.  She has been doing this work for 8 years.

Jemima stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is "keeping poultry." Her biggest challenge is "access to funding."  Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Kuku."

Jemima was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: "Chose Juhudi Kilimo to access funds to boost poultry project."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "How she could access funds from Juhudi Kilimo through the group."

Jemina's highest monthly expense is business related. When asked "How will this loan benefit her family", Jemima replied "Will boost poultry project."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Jemima owns the following: 'poultry' but does not own 'cow, pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'.  Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household:  'mosquito net, electricity, TV, DVD'  but does not have 'solar power, running water, sewing machine'.

loans.use: buy chickens

loans.name: Maluza

texts.en:
Maluza is a 51-year-old single woman living alone in the Khobi district in the Western part of Georgia. Maluza’s only source of income is the small monthly social assistance from the local government, as she belongs to “vulnerable poor” category. Her funds are hardly enough to cover food costs.

Maluza wishes to have some other source of income and to be involved in business. She decided to apply for credit and start a clothes trading business among her community members, as there are not many clothing stores in her district and people can’t afford to buy apparel due to high prices. 

With the received credit Maluza will transport apparel and household items such as pillow cases, towels, etc. from the capital city open market and sell them at reasonable prices. She will also give her customers the opportunity to buy items and pay later. This initiative will attract many customers and Maluza will generate income. She will continue the business and invest her funds in trading again to increase sales volume.

Maluza hopes her activity will be successful and believes in your generosity.

loans.use: to start a clothing trading business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her two children.

She has operated a charcoal selling business; selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she sells firewood and snarks. She faces a stiff competition from other charcoal operators in her business.
 
With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. she decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school, and the rest are adults. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past ten years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Dorcas dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Sien

texts.en: Sien is 49 years old and a mother of four children residing in Kampong Cham province. She manages a four-hectare rice farm as the main source of income with support from her husband. Sien has never been with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) before. Now, she is seeking 3,000,000 KHR in order to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her farmland. She hopes that she can gain a good income from her crop and improve her lifestyle so it is better than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David grew up in a predominantly cattle-keeping family and developed the skill from there. 

With some income given to him by his father, he started buying young bulls at a small price, especially during the dry season when weather was harsh and people were selling cheaply due to the lack of pasture. He later made enough money after he bred them and sold them at high prices and bought more expanding his business. 

The Ugafode loans have also contributed a lot to his expansion. He thanks the Kiva lenders for being interested in partnering with him. He is hard-working and honest.

loans.use: To buy more cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a solar home lighting system to replace diesel lamps

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is 22 years old and supports one child. She has been in this business for the last two years with a monthly income of KSH 40,000. Emily has applied for her first loan with KADET LTD of KES 20,000 to buy vegetable seedlings and chemicals. She will use the anticipated profit to improve her living standard. Her hope and dream is to expand her business to get more profits, which in turn will increase her income.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seedlings and pestcide chemicals

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu operates an open air food selling business, selling dumplings from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business. 

With this KSH 50,000 loan, Tatu wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and salt for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support given from Yehu and Kiva.

loans.use: buy food to resell

loans.name: Kimsan

texts.en:
Kimsan is a 51-year-old local farmer from Kandal Stoeung district in Kandal province.  She is a mother of three children. Currently, only one child still relies on her as this child is still in school. 

To make a living, Kimsan sells vegetables and fish at the local market in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. To earn more income, she also trades rice. 

Since her son is pursuing a bachelor degree at a local university, the expenses in her family are quite a challenge for her recently. Therefore, Kimsan  applied for an education to cover the tuition fee for her son, who wants to have a bachelor degree in Architecture. She hopes that she can fulfill her son's dream.

loans.use: pay her son's college tuition

loans.name: Ramy's Group

texts.en:
Ramy is 35 years old and is a married mother of three children.  Her family relies on rice farming a one-hectare area and the occupation of her husband,  who works for others for a fee. This farm is a business that she has had for 10 years. 

Ramy is a seven-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has fully repaid back her past loans wisely and on  time.  Those loans have helped her support her business and improve her livelihood better than before. 

Now, Ramy is leading a group of three to get a new loan.   She will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer and to pay for the plowing fee for her rice farm. She hopes that she can gain a good yield from her rice field and get a good income to expand her business better than before.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to pay for plowing fee

loans.name: Soeurn's Group

texts.en:
Soeurn, 45 years old and married, is a mother of five children.  They are residing in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province.  The main source of her income is from a pineapple plantation which returns for her about 20,000 KHR per day. 

This is the first-time loan for Soeurn's group of three members with VisionFund (Kiva's partner).  Soeurn is the group leader for this loan cycle.  Soeurn will  spend her loan portion to buy potash for her crop to boost its yield. She hopes to gain a good crop output better than before and get a good selling price.

loans.use: buy potash for her pineapple farm

loans.name: Rrahman

texts.en:
Rrahman is 34 years old, married, and is a father of 4 children between the ages of 2 and 8 years old. Together, they live in the Roma community of Kosovo where two of his children are currently attending school. 

In order to earn a living, Rrahman has been selling used shoes for more than 12 years now. He is able to obtain his supply of used shoes from abroad at low cost and then sells them at a higher price for profit in different markets around Kosovo. In this way he has been able to support his family. 

At this time, Rrahman is requesting a loan in order to purchase a new supply of shoes. He believes that this loan will help him to sustain his business. His future goal is to expand his business and to earn more so that he can give his children a better education. He wants to thank all of the lenders.

loans.use: buy shoes to resell

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen, age 29, is a married woman.  She is a hardworking mother who is helping her husband by providing tailoring services in her community. She is the mother of a young daughter and lives in the area of Lahore, Pakistan, with her husband. 

Parveen has been doing her tailoring business for a couple of years.  Although she has known the techniques of stitching for many years before her marriage, she only chose it as a profession after getting married. Her regular customers belong to the neighborhood and the local community. She earns enough to support her husband.

To help her husband, Parveen continues the operations of her business.  She has requested for a loan to buy a new sewing machine and packs of zippers and buttons to meet the increasing demand. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to pay for personal expenses.

Parveen is very thankful to the Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: buy a sewing machine and sewing supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a solar home lighting system that will provide better lighting in the home

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has two children, one is still young for school. They live in their own house, which has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Fatuma operates a khangas (women wrap clothing) selling business, selling from home and door-to-door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of lack of capital to expand her business.

With this loan she is requesting of KES 50,000, Fatuma wants to purchase 2 bales of khangas for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: buy khangas to resell

loans.name: Sereana Group

texts.en:
Tania is the featured borrower of Sereana’s Group.  She got together with her group members to acquire a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua because they have always been neighbors and friends.
 
Tania is a 20-year-old single lady who is employed in a roastery (a place where nuts and coffee are sold roasted) since two years ago. Tania is her family's sole breadwinner; she is responsible for the living of five members of her family, in addition to covering her own needs. Thus, she has to put in extra effort to cover the unexpected and increasing family needs. 

For this reason, Tania is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to start a new business to make sure that she can develop and improve her family’s living with this extra income. Her acquired loan will be invested in opening a special occasions planning shop, where she will start with birthdays at the beginning since she adores children and loves to draw a smile on every child’s face, but she hopes to widen and expand her dream in the future to be a wedding planner too. 

Tania is the first one at the right side of the picture with the orange top.   As for the other group members, Maya is at the center of the picture wearing a white shirt and Norma is the first lady from the left wearing a black top.

loans.use: start an event planner business

loans.name: Manzese B Group

texts.en:
Veronica, who is in her late 20s, is married and has a child who is in school. For a year now, Veronica has been managing her family by running a business selling soaps of two kinds: liquid and powdered. She starts selling from 8:00am to 8:00pm each working day and is able to make very small return per month. 

This is Veronica's third loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. With the previous loans, all of which were paid back successfully, she restocked more soap for her business. Veronica used her profit to pay for her child's school fees and covered some household expenses. She will use this loan to buy more liquid and powdered soap to resell. Veronica dreams to build a nice family house. 

Veronica will share this loan with her loan group "Manzese B", which consist of 6 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: buy soap to sell

loans.name: Wazo Tegeta Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth, who is in her mid 30s, is single and has one daughter who is still going to school.  She has been running a general store for seven years now. She works from 6.00 am to 11:00 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be Elizabeth's 8th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to restock the missing items in the shop stock and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She used the profit to pay school fees for her child,  covered household expenses and bought a piece of land.  She will us this loan to increase on her shop inventory.  She dreams of building her own house. 

Elizabeth will share this loan with her loan group "Wazo Tegeta" which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: buy inventory for her shop

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer is a married mother of four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees and food for the familly.

Jeniffer operates a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation and competition in her business. 

With this loan that she is requesting of KES 20,000, Jeniffer wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 47-year-old single lady who works in selling accessories, antiques, stationery and mobile phones prepaid cards since nineteen years ago.  This long experience provided her with customer’s trust and support. 

Fatima is the sole breadwinner for 2 members of her family.  That's why she has to work hard and put in so much effort to improve her business income to make sure that she’ll stay capable of covering her family’s living expenses and improve their socioeconomic situation.

Fatima is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise, especially school supplies (stationery and bags).  Concerning the future, Fatima is willing to make necessary decorations to her shop to keep it more attractive to her current and expected customers.  She will also work on expanding her business through introducing her customers to new items that she is planning to start selling in the coming future.

loans.use: buy business merchandise to resell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a master weaver in Peru, specializing in beautiful Andean rugs and tapestries. He would like to stock up on wool and dyes for his creations.

David has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story: his grandparents and parents were weavers, who learned this trade from their predecessors. He essentially learned through observation. Nevertheless, he has taken several textile courses. His work focuses on resuscitating his ancestral culture and linking it to the present. He works with his family, and their materials include wool, cotton, and both natural and industrial dyes. For the natural dyes, he cultivates the plants such as walnut, tare, molle and alder.

He explains further that he is developing tapestry collections using a new technique. He is excited at how well they've been received. And he feels proud that he can carry on his Andean beliefs, customs and myths through his work. He thanks you all so much for your help.

loans.use: to purchase additional wool and dyes for his weaving business

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is 54 years old.  She is the mother of 8 children, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan.  Her husband has grown old and stays at home.  

Jamila sews bags from home along with her two daughters and two sons. She has two sewing machines to sew the bags, which are operated by her daughters.  Both her sons deal with outsiders and take orders from the contractor and sew the bags on order.

Jamila wants to sell her sewed bags directly to the market so that she can get maximum reward against their efforts. But she does not have the initial capital to buy raw materials for making bags.

Jamila requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan so that she can buy raw materials such as rexine, zippers, buckles, etc. for making bags.

Jamila give thanks Kiva and to its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: buy materials to sew bags for sale

loans.name: Granit

texts.en:
Granit is a young man of the age of 24 and recently married. He is a very hard worker who earns a living by providing various services for computers such as formatting and repairing computers. He had been working in a private company with very low salary, but now has decided to open his own business doing this same work that he is very proficient in. 

Granit is requesting a loan in order to buy information technology equipment for completing services needed for computers as well as expand into video game room such as playstations. "Without this loan I will not be able to start my own business" claimed Granit.  He expects to be successful in this business based on his experiences and knowledge. He appreciates all of the lenders for this help.

loans.use: buy computer equipment

loans.name: Kuoy

texts.en:
Kuoy is 52 years old and is a single mother of three grown-up children. She permanently lives with some of her children in Kampong Speu province. She tries hard in her position as a market vendor to constantly raise and educate her children until they have enough abilities to start having independent life and stand by themselves. Two of her children have already settled down for marriage. 

Kuoy can generate a good profit of $9.33 per day from selling fermented fish paste (Prahok in Khmer) in different markets of the province. With the loan she has requested from HKL, she aims to build a water storage made from concrete rings and cement. This storage will allow her to store enough water from the rain for household use without going to collect water from far-distant areas often. 

Kuoy thanks lenders for this constant support. She awaits your kindness and relies on your generosity.

loans.use: to build a water storage tank

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in handcrafted jewelry. He would like to invest in a bulk purchase of silver and natural gemstones.

Carlos has been selling through NOVICA since 2006. This is his story:

"My father was my guide in the world of art.  He was a jeweler and worked at his craft day and night. I was curious about it but didn't really give it much attention. As an adult, I'd go to the mountains to trade scales for grams of gold.  And this is how I became enthused about jewelry.  One day, I stayed watching my father and he suggested I pay close attention to what he was doing. In this way, I began to learn each detail of every piece.  I never attended workshops or courses, as my father was my teacher, although he never gave me a formal class. I learned myself by observing, and never let a single detail get past me.  These days I get up at night to sit and design quietly."

A message from Carlos: "First of all, please receive a big hug for your support through this microcredit. It warms the heart to know there are people out there who are willing to help without expecting anything in return. And you have my word that every piece of jewelry I make will be crafted with high quality materials and loads of love!"

loans.use: to invest in a bulk purchase of silver and natural gemstones

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mariamu is a widowed woman with three school-going children. They live at their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mariamu has been operating a fruits and vegetable stall business for the past fourteen years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future.

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial supports.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Timina

texts.en:
Timina lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya, close to the Ugandan border. It contains the only tropical rain forest in Kenya, and the variety of the flora in the region makes it well suited for beekeeping. It has one of the highest rural population densities in the world (in some areas, close to 600 people per square kilometer), which may contribute to the region's high poverty rates.

Timina is unmarried, and has seven children and many grandchildren. She has been farming for forty years, and is currently growing beans, maize, groundnuts and cassava on her land. She is excited to start beekeeping because she loves honey as medicine, and is looking forward to the income that comes from honey. This is Timina’s first loan, and she plans to use the income from her hives “to build a good house and take care of my grandchildren.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for having the only tropical rain forest in the country. Most farmers in Kakamega grow maize, but sugarcane, papaya, bananas and tea are also popular crops. The variety of crops grown in the region, as well as the abundance of vegetation in the old growth forest, make Kakamega particularly attractive for beekeeping. 

Florence is a single parent with nine children. She has been farming for twenty years, and is currently growing maize and vegetables on her land. She likes beekeeping because the income will help her take care of her family. This is Florence’s first loan, and she plans to use the income to pay school fees for her children and provide for her family. When asked about her hopes for the future, Florence had a definitive answer: “to build a nice house, take my kids to college and buy a dairy cow.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose was born in Nicaragua, where he worked as a public accountant for many years. When he arrived to the United States in 1988, Jose worked at various factories, always juggling at least two jobs, while working to improve his English.

In July 1995, Jose’s friend introduced him to the delivery service industry. Jose really enjoyed the work, and decided to start his own business as an independent delivery truck driver. 

Jose now works in Philadelphia, delivering medicine to various pharmacies. He also makes large deliveries for a Hispanic newspaper company. Jose serves all types of businesses and he continues to expand. Jose says he has developed relationships with his clients and this sets him apart from the competition.

The money from this loan will go towards the purchase of another more efficient van for Jose’s delivery service. Eventually, Jose would like to make bigger deliveries using cargo vans. His long-term goal is to manage a team of 20 vans throughout the tri-state area and Pennsylvania.

loans.use: To purchase a more efficient van for his delivery service

loans.name: Joel-Lean

texts.en:
Joel-Lean moved from Brooklyn, New York to Manassas, Virginia four years ago and found it difficult to find affordable hair care--especially hair braiding. She got the idea to start her own home-based business one year ago. She offers her clients hair care and styling services: trims, removals, braids, twists, dreads, weaves, wigs, etc. 

"I love the idea of providing a service that is going to boost one's self-esteem for an affordable price. I have been given the opportunity to provide a service that is needed in my community. Not only am I their stylist, but I am also a friend, therapist, and anything else my client needs during and after their appointment," she says. 

Joel-Lean is very passionate about the clients she serves and hopes to use the funds to open a storefront and hire an employee.

loans.use: to open a storefront and hire an employee

loans.name: Stahslaus

texts.en:
Stahslaus lives outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega is located in Western Kenya and is famous for the Kakamega Forest, the only tropical rain forest in Kenya. It is a very good location for beekeeping due to the old growth trees in the forest and concentration of farms in the area, which provide bees with a variety of forage. 

Stahslaus is married, and has five children. Both he and his wife are farmers, and are currently growing vegetables and sugarcane on their land as well as tending to a tea plantation. Stahslaus likes beekeeping because the income is attractive, and is a good use of his land. This is Stahslaus’ first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to pay his children’s school fees. His hope for the future is “to live a better life…I want for my kids to go to university.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Atlas World Travel has been in business since 1975 and is a family-owned and operated full-service travel agency. They design their own bus tours for the senior market, and have also designed many trips for high school groups and fundraising organizations.

Gloria has been the owner of Atlas World Travel since the inception of the agency.  In addition to setting the standards and overseeing the general operation, she has been involved in “The Patrons of the Arts”, both as fundraising chairperson and president – a very important part of the Monroe Township community.
 
During the height of a busy season when Hurricane Sandy hit, the travel agency was forced to close down for a two-week period.  Although there was no new revenue produced during that time frame, all employees were paid full salary.
 
The loan given to Gloria will be used to recover from some of the losses realized during Super Storm Sandy.  It will enable her to expand her business by using this money to secure cruise space to market to prospective clients.

loans.use: to secure cruise space for clients of her family-owned travel agency.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is single and has one child who attends school. She rents a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her kid. She owns a retail kiosk business, where neighbours and town dwellers are her potential customers. She faces a major challenge of competition since there are many shops around. With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase more stock of goods like sugar, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat. She dreams of expanding to a modern café in the business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of goods like sugar, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice operates a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high transportation costs. With the loan that she is requesting of KES 30,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She appreciates the support given.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en: Kwekwe is a divorced woman with no children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. For the past three years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. Kwekwe dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With her KES 30,000 loan she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is very thankful to all of the lenders for the previous loan which has helped her to buy agricultural machinery. She is still working together with her husband on her land. Marina is very satisfied with the previous loan and she is asking for a second loan for the same business. 

This time she wants to change the engine of her agricultural machine because it is broken from working a lot on the neighbors' and her land. This business is still her main source of income and she is very happy for this opportunity. Marina also in the future wants to work in agriculture. She wants to thank all of the lenders for the second support!

loans.use: To change the engine of her agricultural machine

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en: Mwanaisha is a married mother with three school-going children. They live at their own house that has no electricity and piped water. She operates a food kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other food kiosk operators in her business. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour and rice for resale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour and rice for resale.

loans.name: Eden Group

texts.es:
El grupo “Edén” es un grupo conformado por cinco integrantes entre hombres y mujeres, todos son muy buenos amigos y entre ellos existe un apoyo incondicional. El nombre del grupo lo eligieron ellos mismos porque es un nombre bíblico, así se llamó el lugar donde Adán y Eva vivían.

Doña Adoración o Dora, como le dicen de cariño, es la representante del grupo, tiene 40 años de edad y está casada con el señor Armando; juntos han formado una familia con una hija que se encuentra estudiando. Doña Dora se dedica a la cría y venta de cerdos desde hace ya seis años platica como fue que inicio su negocio “La cría de los cerdos la inicie por necesidad, también por la falta de un trabajo estable, las saudas o las estructuras para iniciar con la cría de mis cerdos ya estaban porque eran de mis padres". Los padres de Dora también se dedicaban a esta actividad. Doña Dora solo cría y engorda sus lechoncitos para después venderlos mientras que a unas cuantas cerdas las utiliza solo para pie cría cuando estas dan sus  a luz a sus cerditos de inmediato inicia  a buscar su comprador en muchas ocasiones es muy difícil encontrar personas que desean adquirir un lechoncito. Doña Dora además de estar ofreciendo sus lechones con sus vecinos también coloca un letrero afuera de su casa con la leyenda “Se venden lechones”. Esta situación es la dificultad de Dora, es decir, poder encontrar un buen comprador. Ella tiene una amplia experiencia en cerdos porque desde muy chica se vio involucrada en esta actividad. Sus cerdas solo pueden llegar a tener seis o siete lechoncitos en cada camada. Al momento de quedar cargada la cerda se esperan cuatro meses es un periodo de gestación, los lechones nacen y por cuarenta días Doña Dora tiene que tener un cuidado especial con ellos, pasando este tiempo ya puede venderlos. Aunque de ante mano sabe cuál será la dificultadad para vender sus lechones, ella está muy motivada a seguir con su actividad “No hay de otra más que seguir echándole ganas, me gustaría hacer crecer mi negocio tengo las estructuras necesarias para tener los suficientes lechones pero en la comunidad hay muchos vecinos dedicados a la cría y venta de cerdos así no puedo vender ya con mucha facilidad”. Sin embargo la meta de Doña Dora es ver realizado el sueño de su hija que quiere llegar a ser  un medico cirujano. Esta profesión le nació desde pequeña porque siempre sus abuelos eran muy enfermizos, siempre deseo poder ayudar a mejorar su condición. Los miembros del grupo son Wilebaldo quien invertirá en la venta de jarciaría; Álvaro, en la cría, engorda y venta de pollos y guajolotes; José, en la venta de fibras y Rosario, en la cría y engorda de cerdos. Ellos están muy agradecidos por la oportunidad de recibir un préstamo fondeado por personas de diferentes partes del mundo, además porque llevan ya dos años en VFM y ya han visto las mejoría en sus actividades.
texts.en:
The group “Eden” is composed of five people, both men and women. All of them are very good friends and unconditional support exists among them. They chose their name themselves from the biblical name, calling it after the place where Adam and Eve lived.

Adoración, or Dora as she is affectionately called, is the representative of the group. She is 40 years old and married to Armando. They have a daughter who is studying. Dora has been raising and selling pigs for six years saying about starting her business, “Breeding pigs was a necessity because of the lack of stable work and the inclination and framework were already there from my parents to begin raising pigs.” Dora’s parents also work in this field. Dora breeds and fattens some of her piglets to sell later while some of the other pigs are only used for breeding and she starts looking for buyers right away as many times it is hard to find people wanting to buy a piglet.

Dora also offers her piglets through her neighbors placing a sign outside their house reading, “Piglets for sale”. This situation is difficult for Dora, that is to say, finding a good buyer. She has extensive experience in pigs because since she was a young girl she has been involved in this business. 

Her pigs can only have six or seven piglets in each litter.
